question.title: Why does my JButton lose its full width when added via a JPanel in BorderLayout?
question.body:
I’m an absolute beginner with Java Swing and trying to build a simple GUI for a unit converter.

In the following code, I add a JButton directly to the JFrame using BorderLayout.PAGE_END. The button stretches across the entire width of the window, which is exactly what I want:

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import javax.swing.JButton;

public class Main {

    public Main() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setSize(800, 300);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");
        frame.add(convertButton, BorderLayout.PAGE_END);

        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new Main();
    }
}

However, I read online that it’s better practice to add components to a JPanel and then add that panel to the frame. But when I try that, the button is no longer stretched — it stays small:

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import javax.swing.JButton;

public class Main {

    public Main() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setSize(800, 300);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

        JPanel panel = new JPanel();
        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");

        frame.add(panel, BorderLayout.PAGE_END);
        panel.add(convertButton, BorderLayout.PAGE_END); // <-- Why doesn't this work the same?

        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new Main();
    }
}

Why is the button no longer stretched across the width of the frame? Is there a way to keep the recommended JPanel structure but still make the button stretch horizontally like in the first example?

Thanks in advance!

answers.body:
Oracle has a helpful tutorial, Creating a GUI With Swing. Skip the Learning Swing with the NetBeans IDE section. Pay particular attention to the Laying Out Components Within a Container section.

All Swing applications must start with a call to the SwingUtilities invokeLater method. This method ensures that the Swing components are created and executed on the Event Dispatch Thread.

I modified the code in the question to create the following GUI.

I chose to use a GridLayout and put am empty border areound the button JPanel so the button looks nicer.

Here's the complete runnable code.

import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import java.awt.GridLayout;

import javax.swing.BorderFactory;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.SwingUtilities;

public class UnitConverter {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        SwingUtilities.invokeLater(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                new UnitConverter().createAndShowGUI();
            }
        });
    }

    public void createAndShowGUI() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setSize(400, 300);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

        JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridLayout(0, 1));
        panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(5, 5, 5, 5));
        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");
        panel.add(convertButton);

        frame.add(panel, BorderLayout.PAGE_END);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

}

JPanels have a default FlowLayout. One possibility is to use a GroupLayout and group the components up.

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;

public class Main {

    public Main() {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setSize(800, 300);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

        JPanel panel = new JPanel();
        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");

        frame.add(panel, BorderLayout.PAGE_END);

        GroupLayout layout = new GroupLayout(panel);
        panel.setLayout(layout);

        GroupLayout.SequentialGroup hGroup = layout.createSequentialGroup();
        hGroup.addGroup(
            layout.createParallelGroup(GroupLayout.Alignment.TRAILING)
                .addComponent(
                    convertButton,
                    GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE,
                    GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE,
                    Short.MAX_VALUE
                )
        );
        layout.setHorizontalGroup(hGroup);

        GroupLayout.SequentialGroup vGroup = layout.createSequentialGroup();
        vGroup.addComponent(convertButton);
        layout.setVerticalGroup(vGroup);

        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new Main();
    }
}

question_comments.body: The best reason to add components to a JPanel first is to promote ease of code reuse but that is probably academic at the moment

As long as whatever online resource you’ve read doesn’t convincingly explain why it’s supposed to be “better practice to add components to a JPanel and then add that panel to the frame” you can ignore that. At the moment, it only caused you problems and used your time, without providing any advantage.
Oracle has a helpful tutorial, Creating a GUI With Swing. Skip the Learning Swing with the NetBeans IDE section. Pay particular attention to the Laying Out Components Within a Container section.
the default layout of JPanel is NOT a BorderLayout (it is a FlowLayout), the first comment means panel.setLayout(new BorderLayout()) -- the button will use its preferred size with a FlowLayout
So do I have to turn the panel.add(convertButton, BorderLayout.PAGE_END); into panel.add(convertButton); for that and leave the Layout on the Panel? Because the button still seems small
Well the simplest way is to set a BorderLayout on the panel, not that I want to encourage ugly oversized buttons ;)

79565384.body: ok, corrected it. Not enough. The phrases no layout and not organized are both wrong
but that is not what you wrote: "JPanels have no layout."
Well, the default is "FlowLayout", strictly speaking, not the organized way the op wants. It's written in the API reference.

"JPanels have no layout" - can you please provide documentation or proof for that? -- The javadoc states: "Creates a new JPanel with a double buffer and a flow layout." (emphasis added) -- testing also shows a FlowLayout
